page.title: 03ALL SAINTS CHURCH
page.content: {All Saints Church}stands on the south side of the village on what was once the green. The church dates from the thirteenth century, the oldest remaining part being the{chancel.} Originally the congregation would have stood near the chancel arch. Seating was probably provided in the fifteenth century, then box pews were added in the seventeenth century. The{Royal {Coat of Arms}above the door has been there since Henry VIII's reign, the present one since the eighteenth century. The church{organ}was given by Earl Howe in 1844. The stained{glass {window}in the south wall was given by Samuel Knowles, a local farmer. The lectern was given the Rector in 1885 by his own children. The church was extensively restored in 1853 at a cost of Â£1,650, one of many alterations by successive generations.
